div1.head: Diary of Asa F. Paige
div1.p:
Asa F. Paige
Co. D.
N. H. Vols.

div3.head: April 7th 1864.
div3.p: Our regt reported at Concord today having been on furlough 30 days.

div3.head: 14th.
div3.p: Left Concord today for Washington D. C.

div3.head: 15th.
div3.p: We arrived at New York at daylight this morning left town at 3 Oclock A.M. for Phill, arrived at Phill at 9 Oclock this P.M.

arrived in Washington
at ½ 9 went up to the Soldier's rest.

div3.head: 18th.
div3.p: Marched over long bridge this morning to Arlington Hights and went into Camp.

div3.head: 21st.
div3.p:
[Word lined out.]
Reviewed today by Genl. Casey.

div3.head: 25th.
div3.p: Struck Camp today and marched to Alexandria and went on board a Steamer.

div3.head: 26th.
div3.p: Weighed anchor this morning and run down the Potomac to Fortress Monroe.

div3.head: 27th.
div3.p: Landed on Glousester point Va. today went into Camp.

div3.head: 30th.
div3.p: Reviewed today by Maj. Genl Butler.

div3.head:
May 1st.
4th.
div3.p: Embarked on board steamer Galvor and run to Fortress Monroe.

div3.head: 5th.
div3.p: Run up the James river and landed at Bermuda landing.
Took up the lines of march this morning towards Petersburg, threw up rifle pits at Foster's plantation

div3.head: 9th.
div3.p: Had a fight to day in front of Petersburg. tore up 2 miles of the track on the P. and R. - R.R.{1}

div3.head: 13th.
div3.p: We Charged and took a rebel fort today.

div3.head: 15th.
div3.p: We came up with the rebels again at Druries Bluff.

div3.head: 16th.
div3.p: We had a fight today and had to fall back.

div3.head: 18th.
div3.p: The rebeles have drove our pickets in and we are fighting now the fight has stoped for the night.

div3.head: 21st.
div3.p: We had a fight today with the rebs.

div3.head: 28th.
div3.p: Went aboard the Steamer Escort and run to Fortress Monroe.

div3.head: 29th.
div3.p: Ran to West point today

div3.head: 30th.
div3.p: Weighed anchor and run up the Permonky. river and landed at White house.

div3.head: June 4th.
div3.p: Marched from White house this morning to the front, and entrenched ourselves.

div3.head: 5th.
div3.p: the rebs Charged our lines to night and were repulsed.

div3.head: 12th.
div3.p: We marched to White house landing today.

div3.head: 13th.
div3.p: embarked on board Steamer - and run to Fort Monroe.

div3.head: 14th.
div3.p: We ran up the James river and landed at Bermuda hundred.

div3.head: 15th.
div3.p: crossed the Appamacox on the pontoon bridge and drove the rebels from there first line in front of Petersburg it was a pretty hard fight.
The 18th Corps was reinforced to stay by the 2nd Corps, {the 2nd. div. 10th a.c. is transferred to the 18th for the present time.

div3.head: 17th.
div3.p: The 6th Corps came up to day.

div3.head: 19th.
div3.p: Marched to Bermuda hundred and went into Camp.

div3.head: 20th.
div3.p: Went into the trenches at the front to day.

div3.head: 21st.
div3.p: Marched back acrost the Appamacox to the trenches in front of Petersburg.{2}

div3.head: 29th.
div3.p: We were releaved from the front line to night and went into the seconds

div3.head: 30th.
div3.p: We were musturd today for two months pay.

div3.head: July 1st.
div3.p: Our Brigade had a fight to day in our front, it was about til far lat.

div3.head: 3rd.
div3.p: Went into the front trenches and releaved the 91{3}. Penn Vols.

div3.head: 29th.
div3.p: Marched to the front of the 9th Corps tonight.

div3.head: 30th{4}.
div3.p: Rebel fort blown up at ½ 4 O'clock this morning it shook us up pretty good. We had to Charge on the left of the fort{5}.

div3.head: 31st.
div3.p: Marched to Bermuda H. and went into camp tonight.

div3.head: Aug 1st.
div3.p: Today is the first day we have been from under fires for 36 days.

div3.head: 12th.
div3.p: Struck camp at 11 O clock to night and marched to Joneses landing.

div3.head: 13th.
div3.p: Crossed the James on the upper pontoon at daylight this morning.

div3.head: 19th.
div3.p: We moved round to deep bottom last night and moved to the front today.

div3.head: 15th.
div3.p: The 2nd and 10th Corps had a hard battle today.

div3.head: 21st.
div3.p:
The 2nd and 10th Corps recrossed the James last night on the midle and lower pontoons our regt. helped cover the retreat. We are back in our old camp at near Fosters plantation, it is three years today since I enlisted.. The No. of battles up to to day that we have been in is twelve the number of men killed wounded and missing is {365.} the number of miles
we have marched is (250. (miles.)

div3.head: 25th.
div3.p: The rebs Charged our lines this morning but we were repulsed

div3.head: 28th.
div3.p: We marched to the trenches in front of Petersburg got there at ½ 9 Oclock to night.

div3.head: 31st.
div3.p: We were musterd for pay today.

div3.head: Sept 1st.
div3.p:
went into the trenches
to night.

div3.head: Sept. 4th.
div3.p: We got releaved to night.

div3.head: Sept 6tth.
div3.p: We went into the trenches tonight.

div3.head: Sept 9th.
div3.p: We got releaved from the trenches, to night.

div3.head: Sept. 13th.
div3.p: We went into the trenches to night.

div3.head: Sept 16th.
div3.p: We got releaved tonight.

div3.head: Sept 19th.
div3.p: We went into the trenches to night.

div3.head: Sept 22nd.
div3.p: We got releaved from the trenches to night.

div3.head: Sept 25th.
div3.p: We were releaved to night by the 2nd. Corp and went back [-] miles and went into Camp.

div3.head: Sept. 25th.
div3.p:
We struck Camp at 9 Oclock this P.M crossed the Appomat
at 11 Oclock at night crossed the James at ½ past 2. and halted for one hour.

div3.head: Sept. 29th.
div3.p: we started at 4 Oclock this morning and drove the rebs 5 miles on the New Market road charged and drove the rebs, and charged again at 9 Oclock this P.M. but were repulsed, my regt. lost 21 out of 40 men
We took up our position on the old McLellan line 8 miles from Richmond.

div3.head: Dec 7th.
div3.p: We struck camp at 4 Oclock and marched to Bermuda H. front.

div3.head: Dec 8th.
div3.p: started at day break and marched to B - landing embarked on board Steamer Haye

we arived at F. Monroe
at 2 Oclock this morning
weighed anchor and sailed up the Chesapeake to point Lookout Md. started at 5 Oclock this afternoon for Cape Henry
we put to sea at 5 Oclock this P.M.

div3.head: XDec 15th
div3.p: we passed Cape Haterass at day light this morning.

div3.head: Dec 19th.
div3.p:
We run into Beaufort N.C. to
[word lined out]
caulap

div3.head: Dec 20th.
div3.p: went to sea to day and joined the fleet of Wilmington.

div3.head: Dec 21st.
div3.p: at sea and a very heavy storm.

div3.head: Dec 23rd.
div3.p: We ran into Beaufort again to day day

div3.head: Dec 24th.
div3.p:
We rut down and again joined the
fleet fr opp W -

div3.head: Dec 25th.
div3.p: We landed under cover of the Gun boats 2 ½ miles above Fort Fisher{6}, and reembarked after dark.
We left the fleet this morning for F. Monroe.
We arived at F. Monroe to night.

div3.head: Dec 29th.
div3.p:
We left F Monroe
at noon for B. Hundred

div3.head: Dec 30th.
div3.p: We landed at Jones landing at 3 Oclock arived at our Camp at dark. on the New Market road at dark.

div3.head: Jan 3rd. 1865.
div3.p: We struck camp at noon and marched within one mile of Bermuda landing and lay in the woods all night it snowed all night.

div3.head: Jan 4th.
div3.p: We embarked at dark to night.

div3.head: Jan 5th.
div3.p: We left Bermuda at day light this morning arived at F. Monroe at 2 Oclock this P.M.

div3.head: Jan 6th.
div3.p: We left F. Monroe at day light this morning.

div3.head: Jan 7th.
div3.p: We passed Cape Hatrass this afternoon

div3.head: Jan 8th.
div3.p: We arived off Beaufort N.C. this morning.

div3.head: Jan. 12th.
div3.p: We left Beaufort for Wilmington Bar

div3.head: Jan 13th.
div3.p: We arrived off Fort Fisher last night and landed at 9 Oclock this morning on the beach 3 miles from the fort

div3.head: Jan 15th.
Jan 16th.
div3.p: The main magazine of the fort blew up this morning.

div3.head: Jan. 19th.
div3.p: our regt moved to the point to garrison Battery Beauchanan

div3.head: Feb 11th.
div3.p:
We break struck camp at 6 Oclock this morning and
and marched to the point.

div3.head:
Feb. 17th
. 18th.
div3.p:
We marched back and crossed the river at Federal point this to night
morning and marched to the front on the south side of the river.

div3.head: Feb. 19th.
div3.p:
We crossed the river to night within eight miles of the City in small boats.
[a word lined out]

div3.head: {8}Feb 22nd.
div3.p: We took persession of the City of Wilmington to day and drove the rebs 12 miles beyond the City.

div3.head: March 2nd.
div3.p: We marched back within one mile of the town today.

div3.head: March 15th.
div3.p: struck camp at noon and marched to the front 10 miles from the city.

div3.head: March 16 -
div3.p: struck camp at !/2 6 this morning and marched towards Goldsboro

div3.head: March 17 -
div3.p: struck camp at 7 Oclock this morning and marched until 6 P.M.

div3.head: March 18 -
div3.p: struck camp at 1 P.M. and marched until 7 to night.

div3.head: {9}March 19 -
div3.p: marched at 6 this morning marched until ½ 5 to night.

div3.head: March 20 -
div3.p: marched at 7 this morning went into camp at dark
marched at 1 7 this morning and went into camp at 9 P.M.
marched all day

div3.head: March 30 -
div3.p: struck camp at 4 this afternoon and went aboard the cars and run to south Washington 29 miles from Wilmington

div3.head: April 5 -
div3.p: struck camp at this morning and marched to Bergan distance 6 miles

div3.head: April 6 -
div3.p: marched back to south washing to day de day

div3.head: April 8 -
div3.p: struck camp this morning and marched to Magnolia 20 miles from S. W -

div3.head: April 9 -
div3.p: marched. to faisons station to day distance 23 miles.
struck camp at 9 to night and marched until ½ 3.

div3.head: April 12 -
div3.p:
struck camp at 6 this morning and marched
until 8 to night

div3.head: April 13 -
div3.p: marched at 6 this morning

div3.head: April 14 -
div3.p: marched at ½ 6 arived at Raleigh 8 to night.{10}
Left Raleigh at 10 Oclock A.M. Reached Morehead at half past six P.M. embarked on the Steamer Starlight for Fortress monroe.
A.M. 5 Oclock steamed out for home - 5 P.M. passed Cape Hatterass, sea smooth.

A.M. 11 Oclock Came to anchor in Hampton roads. 3. Oclock. I went ashore got transportation for the squad to Baltimore at five. P.M. steamed down Hampton roads for Baltimore arrived in Baltimore the morning of the 30th at seven Oclock.
took the train at noon Oclock for Philadelphia arrived in New York at six P.M. Stayed all night at the New England rooms.

div3.head: 31st.
div3.p: Embarked on the City of Boston steamer down long Island Sound took the cars to New London [New Hampshire] for Wirlister

div1.head: Notes
div1.p:
[Transcription Notes:
Mary Jo Kline's transcription style as suggested in her A Guide To Documentary Editing, Baltimore: The Johns Hopkins Press, 1987, has been followed for Asa Paige's diary. The diary measures 3" X 4 ½ ". The front cover is black leather. The back cover is missing. The paper is lined and somewhat soiled. Every attempt has been made to transcribe this document literally. Spelling and punctuation are reproduced as found. When punctuation and or capitalization have not been used by the author, three spaces are inserted to denote the end of one thought and the beginning of another When words are inserted above the line by the author, the symbol "^" is used with the inserted words bracketed. See page 8 for McLell^'an'. Insertions by the transcriber are placed within square brackets. To denote a missing word, [-] is used. If a word or proper name is unclear, a question mark is inserted, such as Wirlister [?].]

note.p: [[The date skips to the 29th. Perhaps a page is missing from this diary.]
[Petersburg mine explosion and assault - Battle of the Crater.]

["Nearly sixty warships continued the Federal bombardment of Fort Fisher, easily hitting the parapets and traverses of the sand-built fort. Meanwhile, the Federal troops landed two miles north, captured a battery, and pushed close to the fort itself. However, as darkness came on, Confederate troops closed in from the north. Furthermore, assault was deemed too expensive in lives, so the troops were taken off (the last on Dec. 27) and the whole fleet returned to Hampton Roads, devoid of success but with light casualties. Fort Fisher still stood active at the entrance to the Cape Fear River." - Long, E.B. Civil War Day by Day: An Almanac 1861-1865, p. 615.]
["The result ....was significant; Wilmington was cut off as a blockade- running port and it has been the last major access point for the South." Long, E. B., Civil War Day by Day, p. 625.]
